H0.text: Radiation is the way heat transfers from the dark wall, which has become warm while the Sun is shining, to a person standing a meter away after the Sun sets, allowing the person to feel the wall’s warmth.

H1.text: Conduction is the process by which heat transfers from a dark‑colored wall that becomes warm when the Sun is shining to a person standing one meter away after the Sun sets.

H2.text: Convection is the heat transfer mechanism that carries warmth from a dark‑colored wall, which becomes warm when the Sun is shining, to a person standing a meter away after the Sun sets.

H3.text: Insulation is the process by which a dark‑colored wall that becomes warm when the Sun shines on it continues to transfer heat to a person standing a meter away after the Sun sets, allowing that person to feel the wall’s warmth.

A4.text: Thermal radiation is emitted by all objects at temperatures above absolute zero, due to random movements of atoms and molecules in matter.

A5.text: Clothing can be considered an insulator which provides thermal resistance to heat flow over the covered portion of the body.
